newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Six groups want to bid on Brazil telecoms stake.
newsitem.headline: Six groups want to bid on Brazil telecoms stake.

text.p: Six foreign-led consortia have applied to take part in the November auction of a 35-percent stake in a Brazilian state-owned telecommunications company, officials said.

Rio Grande do Sul state's mines, energy and communications office said in a statement that officials will decide in 10 days which groups passed the second, final prequalification round to bid on shares of the state's Companhia Riograndense de Telecomunicacoes (CRT).
The groups, made up of 11 foreign and 14 local companies, have a total net worth of 186 billion reais, roughly four times the gross domestic product of Rio Grande do Sul state, officials said.

"This demonstrates the interest that exists in the process and confirms we have chosen the best path for CRT," state Mines, Energy and Communications Secretary Assis Roberto de Souza was quoted as saying.
* France Telecom with locals Banco Opportunity, Employees Fund and Telos. The group's net worth: 46.5 billion reais.
* Korea Telecom of South Korea, with Odebrecht, Stelar Telecom, Unibanco and Folha de Sao Paulo. Net worth: 18.4 billion reais.
* Italy's STET and Argentina's Perez Companc S.A. with locals Camargo Correa and Bradesco. Net worth: 27.6 billion reais.
* Telefonica Internacional de Espana of Spain with Brazil's RBS Participacoes S.A. and Cia de Telecomunicaciones de and Citicorp. Net worth: 39.2 billion reais.
* GTE Corp's GTE International Telecommunications Inc. Net worth: 6.9 billion reais.
* Japan's Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Co with Itochu Corp and Cia Suzano de Papel e Celulose of Brazil. Net worth: 74.3 billion reais.
Seven groups had passed the first prequalification round last month.
Those prequalified after the second round will learn the sale mechanism and gain access to CRT's financial and technical data in October, the statement said.
Analysts see the CRT shares selloff as a litmus test for the upcoming privatization of Brazil's giant federally owned Telebras telecoms system. CRT is not part of Telebras.

By opening CRT to private capital, the state hopes to land a strategic partner "who can add technology, investment capital and management to reduce the pent-up demand for telephone lines n Rio Grande do Sul," Roberto de Souza said.
A winning bidder will be picked in December.
